hello -

 I'm new to nihonto, so please be kind! 

 I've acquired an intere=
sting shin gunto with the following traits:  

- tang signed nakata sukehor=
i, according to fred. weissberg 
- black lacquered (not painted) wooden say=
a with field cover in fine pigskin; ink stamps 
inside
- a fine mirror-poli=
sh blade with good, continuous ("active"?) hamon
- tsuba hole for the relea=
se button, but button missing; (the circular piece above the
grip is late-w=
ar and lacks this feature)
- grip has typical  WWII furniture.

so some bas=
ic questions::

* what's the chance that this is the "old" goto sukehori an=
d not nakata?
* how to distinguish machine-made from hand-made blade?
* why=
 would sukehori sign a machine-made blade?
*  with an 8-power loupe I detec=
t no "grain." proof of a machine-made blade?
*  the very edge of the blade =
seems to have sharpening (very thin - ca. 1/16").  Is this
as I hope the or=
iginal edge? 
* could the saya be an old one since it's lacquered?
* since =
the grip still has the sharkskin, safe to assume it's late but not VERY lat=
e war
(when fishskin was abandoned)?
* the field cover seems to have shrunk=
 over the saya. I'd like to see the scabbard in its 
glory. but -  best lea=
ve alone?
* are the stamps in the saya cover more likely inspectors' or own=
er's?

many thanks for the patience and help with these queries!

I'll try =
to load a few pix....
